Metadata: "Handbook of Coastal and Ocean Engineering," Volume 2: Offshore Structures Marine Foundations Sediment Processes and Modeling, John B. Herbich, ed., pp. 651-680, 1990.

When waves reach the coast and break on a beach, they are observed to generate a variety of currents in the nearshore. Two principal current patterns can be distinguished that may be considered as end members or limiting cases within an otherwise continuum of flow-field types. The objective of this chapter is to review the mechanisms of nearshore- current generation. The focus will be primarily on two limiting cases because they contrast their basic modes of formation.
